column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Create Backgrounds in Artwork
#Text=To simplify art creating , there are two major parts .
#Text=One is the focal point , where your eye rests , and the background which is the reference for the main focal point .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Know what power your background can have .
#Text=A beginning artist is likely to draw or paint a person from a photograph or from real life .

#Text=If you have studied drawing , you know about proportion , shading , the value of using good paper , a set of drawing pencils , the use of pastels , charcoal , or how to do the same using watercolor or acrylic paint .
#Text=But to really demonstrate your talent , you should also include some type of background .
#Text=The background is the key for showing the environment , or surroundings , location , a culture , historical reference , a person ’s status , or circumstance for the artwork .
#Text=This is true for drawing a house , people , animals , a still life , or imaginary characters .
#Text=Look at your subject closely .
#Text=This will help you decide how to form your background .
#Text=Ask yourself some questions ( using a house as an example , but other subjects apply ) :
#Text=When drawing your house , the house needs reference information .
#Text=Is it a ranch style with a garage and a big tree out front ?
#Text=Is it a smaller home in the country with a pond and animals standing by the barn ?
#Text=What makes this house so special you want to draw it ?
#Text=Look for actual details showing where the mailbox is , how many bushes are in the yard .
#Text=Is the house being drawn on a sunny day or a cool autumn day when the family is out raking leaves together ?
#Text=This captures the moment and makes the simple house drawing tell a story .
#Text=Do not place the objects you are drawing in the dead center of the paper .
#Text=Being slightly off the mid-point will add interest , especially if you are drawing a group of objects such as flowers in a vase , a coffee mug and a newspaper .
#Text=Each of these objects has an unique shape and height , and the background should work to located where these objects can be seen , in the kitchen , your end table , the back patio , etc.
#Text=Look at your walls .
#Text=Besides the color of the walls , there are windows , entry ways , bedroom doors , clocks , awards , family photos , furniture , a t. v. , bookshelves and other items piled up .
#Text=Take in a visual inventory of the interior space and list things for the next time you do n’t know what to add to your drawing .
#Text=Also , do n’t make the background too busy or unrelated to the focal area .
#Text=American Gothic by Grant Wood has little background but it says a lot .
#Text=Consider composition .
#Text=Artists use a term called composition which means understanding the placement of visual elements .
#Text=Using a type of grid , good composition places some things above the center and others below , especially in landscape drawing .
#Text=Use a horizon line to show subjects in the distance .
#Text=Objects which are closer are larger , and they become smaller in the distance .
#Text=Plan the setting .
#Text=Using all you know about background information , think of the setting .
#Text=For an drawing exercise , think of what would you see out your window if you lived in NYC versus a window in rural Iowa ?
#Text=Draw what you know best or use photos if you can not picture it .
#Text=Use developed lines and textures .
#Text=Practice using the side of the pencil , make marks which are dots , dashes , short strokes and curved .
#Text=These techniques will enrich the overall quality of your drawing and make your drawing become a real standout .
#Text=Above all , do not leave the background empty .
